Class HeatMap

java.lang.Object
  java.awt.Component
      java.awt.Container
          javax.swing.JComponent
              javax.swing.JPanel
                  HeatMap
All Implemented Interfaces:
java.awt.image.ImageObserver, java.awt.MenuContainer, java.io.Serializable, javax.accessibility.Accessible
public class HeatMap
extends javax.swing.JPanel

Title: HeatMap

Description: HeatMap is a JPanel that displays a 2-dimensional array of data using a selected color gradient scheme.

For specifying data, the first index into the double[][] array is the x- coordinate, and the second index is the y-coordinate.

There are a number of defined gradient types (look at the static fields), but you can create any gradient you like by using either of the following functions:

  • public static Color[] createMultiGradient(Color[] colors, int numSteps)
  • public static Color[] createGradient(Color one, Color two, int numSteps)
You can then assign an arbitrary Color[] object to the HeatMap as follows: 
heatMap.updateGradient(heatMap.createMultiGradient(new Color[] {Color.red, Color.white, Color.blue}, 256));

By default, the graph title, axis titles, and axis tick marks are not displayed. Be sure to set the appropriate title before enabling them.

public void setCoordinateBounds(double xMin,

                                double yMin,
                                double yMax)
Specify the coordinate bounds for the map. Only used for the axis labels, which must be enabled seperately. Calls repaint() when finished.

Parameters:
xMin - The lower bound of x-values, used for axis labels
xMax - The upper bound of x-values, used for axis labels

updateGradient

public void updateGradient(java.awt.Color[] colors)
Updates the gradient used to display the data. Calls drawData() and repaint() when finished.

Parameters:
colors - A variable of type Color[]

createGradient

public static java.awt.Color[] createGradient(java.awt.Color one,
                                              java.awt.Color two,
                                              int numSteps)
Creates an array of Color objects for use as a gradient, using a linear interpolation between the two specified colors.

Parameters:
one - Color used for the bottom of the gradient
two - Color used for the top of the gradient
numSteps - The number of steps in the gradient. 250 is a good number.

createMultiGradient

public static java.awt.Color[] createMultiGradient(java.awt.Color[] colors,
                                                   int numSteps)
Creates an array of Color objects for use as a gradient, using an array of Color objects. It uses a linear interpolation between each pair of points.

Parameters:
colors - An array of Color objects used for the gradient. The Color at index 0 will be the lowest color.
numSteps - The number of steps in the gradient. 250 is a good number.

generateSinCosData

public static double[][] generateSinCosData(int dimension)
This function generates an appropriate data array for display. It uses the function: z = sin(x)*cos(y). The parameter specifies the number of data points in each direction, producing a square matrix.

Parameters:
dimension - Size of each side of the returned array
Returns:
double[][] calculated values of z = sin(x)*cos(y)

generatePyramidData

public static double[][] generatePyramidData(int dimension)
This function generates an appropriate data array for display. It uses the function: z = Math.cos(Math.abs(sX) + Math.abs(sY)). The parameter specifies the number of data points in each direction, producing a square matrix.

Parameters:
dimension - Size of each side of the returned array
Returns:
double[][] calculated values of z = Math.cos(Math.abs(sX) + Math.abs(sY));

updateData

public void updateData(double[][] data)
Updates the data display, calls drawData() to do the expensive re-drawing of the data plot, and then calls repaint().

Parameters:
data - The data to display, must be a complete array (non-ragged)

paintComponent

public void paintComponent(java.awt.Graphics g)
The overridden painting method, now optimized to simply draw the data plot to the screen, letting the drawImage method do the resizing. This saves an extreme amount of time.

Overrides:
paintComponent in class javax.swing.JComponent
